instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message: I found a small amount of corrosion on the usb-c ports. I have cleaned them but the board won't request 20v. I cannot see any damage on the rest of the board. I'm getting 5v 400ma on both sockets. <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> are all giving around 3.4v <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3001</RESISTOR> are also giving 3.4v. I'm not sure where to look next. I'm thinking that the socket may be shorted to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check voltage and diode mode to ground at all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> LDO rails.
Also check <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma

<CHIP>U9911</CHIP> is giving 3.4v on pin 6

DZ9927 is giving 13v on pin 2

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
Don't use boardview when specify MLB readings.
We need to look at schematic to understand what happens.
You can use the boardview to locate test pints, but PLEASE post schematic refference; signal name, or pin component.

<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip has 4 LDO rails.
You've specified 1V1 LDO for <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, but not for <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
Also you've missed one 1V8 LDO for <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

Do you get 1V1 LDO on both chips?
It will apear only on the powered port!

Look at USB-C redriver chip if not burnt.
It doesn't appear on schematic, nor boardview; placed on the other board side, opposite to <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
Okay. I think I understand. I'll do that. Thank you.

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> gives 1.78V

The readings I'm getting on diode mode fluctuate wildly. On that test pad I'm getting 1.5 MΩ and climbs. Some of the others went from their initial reading to the same thing. I'm not very familiar with this way of testing for a short to ground so I don't know if i'm doing the right thing.

and I clearly didn't read your message fully

It will apear only on the powered port!"

:D

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
You can't get K/M ohm values in diode mode.
Multimeter will show "V" when switched to diode mode.
However, do not post the "V" for diode mode readings; avoid misunderstoods.

Read this thread for more information:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

One USB port is damaged.
You should compare (proper) diode mode readings between both ports (on the same pins).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
Boardview and schematic don't show USB-C port terminals.
You must find corresponding points in the MLB, checking continuity from J3300 to USB-C terminals.
You will need good board to find the traces; the bad one doesn't have continuity.
If broken traces are not in MLB (or bad solders at J3300), then need to change the USB port...

You must get the same readings on diode mode at USB-C terminals like good board.

In case, the same pins do not have another available test points on their traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
Checking everything again this morning. Now not getting some LDO rails and not getting PP3V3 or PPBUS. Still at 20v 200mA.

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.8v 0.452,, Pin 12 PP3v3_UPC_XA__LDO = 3.284v 0.477,, Pin 35 <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0v 0.461,, Pin 75 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 1.78v 0.483

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.79v 0.448,, Pin 12 PP3v3_UPC_XB__LDO = 3.32v 0.478,, Pin 35 <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0v 0.457,, Pin 75 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 1.8v 0.48

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0v 0.338

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0v 0.394

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
The problem is not in USB-C area, if you get 20V on both USB-C ports.

Do you get <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage?
Post diode mode to ground at F7000 and L6995.

For the future, do not waste time searching for iGPU voltage; nor even on working board!

"I thought I was that was the "big coils""
And you've only seen L7410/20/30 ont the board?

There are some other smaller coils, which enter in the same "big" category.
You've just stopped on the irrelevant ones.

Post <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> voltages...

Apologies.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5G</SIGNAL>?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.message:
I don't know if i'm doing something wrong.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is permanently 0v while shorting both <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
SMC must send drop pulse to PCH, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
If you detect such drop pulse (<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>), then the problem is on PCH side.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> starts at 3.31v drops immediately to 0.34v then back to 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> starts at 0v and does not change after trigger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> starts at 3.31v drops immediately to 0.34v then back to 3.31v"
All <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals should pulse at same tyime.
If not, the problem is PCH related.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V 400ma
threads.message:
"When I remove <CHIP>U8205</CHIP> from the donor board, is there a way to test that it is good before installing?"
When I don't quote something, the reply is for your previous post.

If enable signal still low after removing <CHIP>U8205</CHIP>, then the chip doesn't cause the problem; so <CHIP>U8205</CHIP> should be good.

When I don't quote something, the reply is for your previous post.
[/QUOTE]

With <CHIP>U8205</CHIP> there is still no voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3S5G</SIGNAL>
